results.title: The Love bug
results.creator_credit: Robert Stevenson, Bill Walsh and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.brief_description: Herbie is one of Disney’s most popular live action characters. Affectionately nicknamed ‘The Love Bug’, Herbie teams up with an unsuccessful race-car driver, Jim Douglas. Jim is amazed to find his driving improves in his new car, but realises the success is due to the car with a mind of its own when someone tries to steal Herbie. Starring Dean Jones, David Tomlinson, Michele Lee and Buddy Hackett.

results.title: The Louvre (PC)
results.brief_description: Take an armchair trip through le Grand Louvre in Paris and discover why it is one of the world’s great museums. There is the option of taking guided tours of the masterpieces and being provided with narration, a history of the building and playing the cour caree game where you can reassemble paintings to your own specifications. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: 486 DX or higher (Pentium recommended), Windows 3.1 or higher, 8 MB of RAM, 4Mb hard drive space, 2x speed CD-ROM drive (4x recommended), 640x480 screen, 256 colors (32,000 recommended).

results.title: The Lost world of the Maya
results.creator_credit: David Collison and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: For over a thousand years the Maya civilisation grew and flourished in the rain forests of Central America until it was discovered and destroyed by the Spanish conquistadores. Eric Thompson, well-known authority on the Maya, describes the struggle to comprehend the vanished civilisation, and the fight to preserve its treasures for posterity. Sites featured are Tikal, Palenque, Yaxchilan, Copan, Quirigua, Chichen Itza, Uxmal and Tulum.

results.title: The Lost weekend
results.creator_credit: Billy Wilder, Charles Brackett and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: This classic Hollywood drama scooped the Oscars in 1945 and it is not surprising. Ray Milland is an alcoholic writer who cannot control his binge drinking. Over a torturous weekend we see how the lure of alcohol has destroyed his confidence, his self-respect and his ambition. As it threatens to eat away at his talent, he comes closer and closer to suicidal despair. From a contemporary perspective the moralistic ending may appear trite but what is undeniable is Billy Wilder’s talent at creating a film which seems to visually simulate the terrifying perspective of a drug user’s imagination. Milland too is excellent as a man who is unable to reach the goals he sets himself. As a study of writer’s block, “The Lost Weekend” is both perceptive and illuminating. Jane Wyman appears as his long-suffering lover, however the book’s original narrative linked the writer’s fear of failure to his ambiguous sexuality. An outstanding film. Based on the book by Charles Jackson.

results.title: The Lost wax method of bronze casting
results.creator_credit: Leo Steiner, Harmon Foundation and Fotosonic
results.brief_description: Vincent Kofi, a Ghanian sculptor, is shown making a bronze casting of his “Awakening Africa” using the lost wax method. The process - from modelling the original clay figurine to the finished work on the metal casting - is shown.

results.title: The Lost tribe
results.creator_credit: John Laing, Gary Hannam, New Zealand Film Commission and Meridian Films
results.brief_description: In this suspense thriller, a missing anthropologist is given up for lost by his wife (Darien Takle) and twin brother Edward (John Bach), but his daughter (Emma Takle) is convinced something odd is involved in her father’s disappearance. Events conspire to put the three people together on a manhunt for the anthropologist amongst a “lost” tribe in the dense jungle of the southern island of New Zealand.

results.title: The Lost soldier
results.creator_credit: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Saunders reflects on the silence reverie of his father, a returned soldier. He never spoke about the war and, when Ken tried to broach the subject, told Ken to let sleeping dogs lie. This left Ken wondering about the demons that his dad confronts alone and the war that took his brother Harry. Spurred by the belief that all warriors need to come home, Ken initiates his own research to find out all he can about Harry and, eventually, return his brother’s spirit home.

results.title: The Lost singing = Shi qu de ge sheng
results.creator_credit: Shi Wei and Tianjin Film Studio
results.brief_description:
This film is about the impact of divorce families on kids. Liang Lili is a Year 4 student and has an excellent singing voice. She is selected for a competition by the Art Troupe of the Children’s Palace. Lili is excited to share the good news with her parents. But what awaits at home is her parents’ quarrelling. Lili’s dad moved out, Lili’s mum couldn’t cheer up, and Lili’s study was affected. One day, Lili saw her father with another woman and realized that the worst would happen. Her parents divorced and the smile in Lili’s face was gone. Lili’s mum relocated to another city and Lili’s dad moved back with the lady and her son. Lili hates the new “mum” and the “little brother”, who broke her piggy bank. The “hatred” between Lili and her new brother escalated, which worried their parents. One night, Lili and her brother were both lonely, each missing their own separated parent. The two kids started to feel sympathetic with each other as both suffered the same. In order to help her brother to go back to see his father, Lili saved money to buy a ticket for him. The two kids said good bye at the train station, and Lili decided to go and look for her mum.

Directed by a female director, the film shows that family melodrama is a recurring theme in Chinese cinema. Director Shi Wei began her career as an actress and acted in films such as Tracks in the Snowy Forrest, an extremely popular film of the 1960s.
Tianjin Film Studio was established in 1958.
The significance of the film lies in that it dealt with a less-discussed topic as divorce was very uncommon in the early 1980s in China. Not much background information about the film could be found. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)

results.title: The Lost pharaoh: the search for Akhenaten
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Kendall, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The fascinating story of an ancient Pharaoh and the archaeological sleuthing which went into piecing together information about his life. An accidental discovery in 1975 by Canadian archaeologist Dr. Donald Redford and his team led to the uncovering of the foundation of one of Akhenaten’s temples. Commentary and narration by Donald Brittain.

results.title: The Lost James Brown tapes
results.creator_credit: Alan Douglas, Chris Mould and Gravity
results.brief_description: Exciting live concert footage of the master of funk and godfather of soul, the inimitable James Brown. Supposedly shot in Monterey, California in 1979, this live concert shows the master in fine form. His powerful voice and trademark dance moves don’t disappoint but the transition to DVD format is a little dubious (may have been shot off a television screen). The ten songs featured are: “Get up offa that thing”, “Body heat”, “Try me”, “Sex machine”, “Georgia on my mind”, “Please please please”, “Hindsight”, “Can’t stand it”, “Papa’s got a brand new bag” and “Jam”. Original producers of the live concert footage were Eric Therman, Rod Crowe and Robert Sheridan. The title listed on the cover (as opposed to the actual work) is “James Brown: Body Heat Live”.
